A group of orientalists have conducted some investigations regarding the author, including Minorsky, Armenyakov, and Brockelmann, without reaching a decisive conclusion. The summary of these investigations is that the author lived in the third Hijri century. Another opinion says he lived around 340 AH, and a third opinion is that he lived in a period not exceeding 454 AH, the year in which the city of Marrakesh [Marrakesh, Morocco] was founded, which was not mentioned by him. There are those who said that the author was Andalusian, evidenced by the presence of echoes of the Andalusian dialect in his book Akam al-Marjan.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: Introduction to the Investigation. In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Since the twenties of this century, the book (Akam al-Marjan) has remained a subject of research due to the ambiguity surrounding it and its author. The author, Ishaq bin al-Husayn al-Munajjim, is semi-unknown; nothing is known about him except his name. However, we certainly know that the manuscript is Yemeni, written by its scribe "Ahsan bin Ali bin Ubayd Allah al-Ansi al-Kawkabani," which he "served to the Commander of the Faithful Al-Qasim bin al-Husayn," one of the Imams of Yemen, who assumed power from the year 1128 AH until his death in the year 1139 AH. The manuscript concluded with the completion of its copying in the month of Sha'ban 1129 AH. Mrs. Angiolo Codazzi described the Ambrosiana manuscript, stating that it consists of 33 papers measuring 21.5 x 20.1 cm with 12 lines per page. Some stains mixed with the manuscript on papers 5-6 and 30-31, and it is...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...written in Yemeni Naskh script, and it is marred by many errors, while the back of the first paper and the face of the second paper were written in a beautiful Thuluth script «1». The book was published through the efforts of Mrs. Codazzi, but it remained full of errors, whether from words lacking dots or words written incorrectly. However, the major errors that marred this work are what was omitted from the copy, sometimes reaching entire paragraphs, or the omission of definitions of entire cities and provinces. I have attempted in my work to rectify what was omitted and present this compilation in a form that corrects most of the errors that appeared in it. A group of orientalists conducted some investigations regarding the author, including Minorsky, Armenyakov, and Brockelmann, without reaching a decisive conclusion. The summary of these investigations is that the author lived in the third Hijri century. Another opinion says he lived around 340 AH, and a third opinion is that he lived in a period not exceeding 454 AH, the year in which the city of Marrakesh [Marrakesh, Morocco] was founded, which was not mentioned by him. There are those who said that the author was Andalusian, evidenced by...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...the presence of echoes of the Andalusian dialect in his book «2». The matter is made more confusing by his omission of the authors or narrators from whom he took information, with the exception of the mention of the name Qutaybah in his discussion of Isfahan [Isfahan, Iran]. Since I expected there to be an error in the name, I reviewed what Ibn Qutaybah wrote in (Al-Akhbar al-Tiwal) about the conquests of the East, but I found nothing. I returned to examine Andalusian sources, and found Ibn Khaldun declaring his sources by stating that he "aligns" in his geographical information "with what appeared in the book Nuzhat al-Mushtaq fi Ikhtiraq al-Afaq, which was authored by Al-Alawi Al-Andalusi Al-Hamoudi for the King of Sicily from the Franks, who is Roger [Roger II], when he was staying with him in Sicily after Sicily exited the Emirate of Malaga. His authorship of the book was in the middle of the sixth century, and he collected for it numerous books by Al-Masudi, Ibn Khurdadhbih, Al-Hawqali, Al-Qardi, Ibn Ishaq al-Munajjim, Ptolemy, and others" «3». As for Al-Idrisi, born in the city of Ceuta [Ceuta, Spain] in the year 493 AH, he declared in "Nuzhat al-Mushtaq" his sources "by seeking what is in the books...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...authored in this art of science as well, all of it. Such as Al-Aja'ib by Al-Masudi, the book of Abu Nasr Sa'id al-Jayhani, the book of Abu al-Qasim Muhammad al-Hawqali al-Baghdadi, the book of Janakh bin Khaqan al-Kimaki, the book of Musa bin Qasim al-Qardi, the book of Ahmad bin Ya'qub known as al-Ya'qubi, the book of Ishaq bin al-Husayn al-Munajjim, and the book of Ptolemy the Claudian..." «4». Our writer belongs to the school of mathematical geography, the foundations of which were laid by Ptolemy. The rules of this school are summarized by dividing the world into seven climes (regions), and relying on lines of longitude and latitude to locate cities and villages. Ishaq bin al-Husayn clarified his reliance on "the first line of the earth, which is the line of the West, and the Equator, which is the middle line of the earth." Although "Al-Akam" appears as a geographical dictionary, the author followed a special approach in which he blended presenting the importance of the city and the cities of a single region, abandoning alphabetical order. He presents the Islamic holy cities first, then returns to Baghdad [Baghdad, Iraq] "because it is the origin of cities," then to Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra) [Samarra, Iraq], which is the second capital of the Abbasids, then to Kufa [Kufa, Iraq], Basra [Basra, Iraq], and Wasit [Wasit, Iraq], the first garrison cities that...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...were built by the Arabs. Then he moves to the south of the Arabian Peninsula, mentioning the city of Sanaa [Sanaa, Yemen] "may Allah the Almighty protect it," then Aden [Aden, Yemen], Oman, Saba, Ma'rib [Marib, Yemen], Hadhramaut [Hadhramaut, Yemen], Socotra [Socotra, Yemen], Bahrain, Hajar, then Taif [Taif, Saudi Arabia] and Al-Yamama. Then the author continues his direction towards the Levant (Bilad al-Sham), and from there to the countries of the Islamic East, to Azerbaijan, Hamadan [Hamadan, Iran], and Nahavand [Nahavand, Iran], then Isfahan [Isfahan, Iran] and Rayy [Rayy, Iran], until he reaches Kerman [Kerman, Iran], Khwarazm, Balkh [Balkh, Afghanistan], Bukhara [Bukhara, Uzbekistan], and Samarkand [Samarkand, Uzbekistan]. What we notice about what he wrote in this section of his geography: A- The author's admiration for both Baghdad and Sanaa. In the first, he is influenced by what he read or quoted from the works of geographers, where the features of Al-Ya'qubi, Ibn Rustah, Ibn Khurdadhbih, Ibn al-Faqih, and Al-Istakhri appear, to the point that entire passages agree with what appeared in those sources. In the second, loyalty to his homeland appears apparent, and if there is an initial assumption saying the author is of Andalusian origin, this does not prevent his sympathy with Yemen, and he likewise provides detailed information about the south of the peninsula. B- In the author's discussion of the Levant, we see him talking about Antioch [Antakya, Turkey] during his discussion of Aleppo [Aleppo, Syria]. Yet he considers it the capital of the Islamic Frontiers, which is what Antioch was before the year 358 AH / 959 AD, the year of its fall into the hands of the leaders of the Emperor...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...Nikephoros Phocas the Byzantine. He talks elsewhere about the successive wars between the Arabs and the Byzantines in (the lands of Sham). C- Beside that, Ishaq bin al-Husayn provides new information that no one before him had presented. He is the first Arab source to mention the Ili River during his discussion of the city of Jurjan, and is almost the only one who indicated that Khwarazm was known as Al-Jurjaniyah. In addition to this, our author provides information about the land tax (Kharaj) of the countries of the East, the origins of their inhabitants, and some industries for which they were famous, with complete brevity, and here he is close to economic geography. In the second section of his geography, our author moves to talk about the regions of Africa. He starts with Alexandria [Alexandria, Egypt], Damietta [Damietta, Egypt], Tinnis, and Misr (Fustat) [Old Cairo, Egypt], then moves to Madyan, and returns to Ain Shams [Heliopolis, Egypt] and Suez (Al-Qulzum) [Suez, Egypt]. Then he moves to North Africa, starting with Tripoli [Tripoli, Libya], then to Sirte [Sirte, Libya] and Ajdabiya [Ajdabiya, Libya], then returns to the Gulf of Aqaba (Ayla) [Aqaba, Jordan], and moves again to Ifriqiya mentioning Kairouan [Kairouan, Tunisia], then to Tahert [Tiaret, Algeria]. Before concluding this section, the author pauses to apologize that he will mention the locations generally and broadly, seeking brevity and abbreviation. After that, he continues to the land of the Berbers, mentioning Tenes [Tenes, Algeria], then moves...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...to Kastiliya [Tozeur region, Tunisia], Fez [Fez, Morocco], Cordoba [Cordoba, Spain], Melilla [Melilla, Spain], Tlemcen [Tlemcen, Algeria], Nakur, Ceuta [Ceuta, Spain], Tangier [Tangier, Morocco], Aghmat [Aghmat, Morocco], and Sijilmasa [Sijilmasa, Morocco] "the last of the Berber lands." Afterwards, the author moves to the land of Sudan, by which he means the Zanj. He mentions some of the lands in Abyssinia [Ethiopia], Mali, and Nubia. Before we move with the author to Europe, we pause to record the following observations: A- That the cities or places mentioned by the author are characterized by being cities deep-rooted in history, or that some of them are historical stations (Alexandria, Misr, Madyan, Carthage, Kairouan, Tinnis). B- Most of the places are characterized by being seaports and centers for maritime trade activity, or they are overland trade stations, and here he touches upon the historical geography of the Islamic world. And if we sense the occurrence of this matter without a declaration from the author, Abu Ubayd al-Bakri al-Andalusi was clear in this regard. In his discussions on North Africa, he would always point to the ports and the corresponding ports on the eastern shores of Andalusia, and he also insisted on highlighting the strong relationship between the ports of both shores.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: C- The author did not address the mention of Cairo, which was founded by Jawhar in the year 359 AH and to which Al-Mu'izz the Fatimid moved in the year 362 AH. This is undoubtedly an important event, whether on the political level, with the arrival of Fatimid influence to Egypt and its threatening of the Levant, or on the intellectual level which mandated the establishment of Al-Azhar Mosque as a center for graduating Fatimid preachers and spreading their doctrine. Then the author moves to talk about Andalusia. Here we see him as knowledgeable and observant. He talks about its coastal administrative units, then moves to the interior, and places the region of the Frontiers (Al-Thughur) against what corresponds to it of Christian Spain. This is accompanied by a presentation containing historical information about the conquest of Andalusia. But he stops us with the information he provided about conditions contemporary to him. While talking about Valencia [Valencia, Spain], Ishaq bin al-Husayn said: "It is near the sea, and its base today is Almeria [Almería, Spain], and it is on the Levantine Sea." Then he mentions the city of (Abrara??) and says: "And its base today is Denia [Dénia, Spain]." The second part of this discussion contradicts the first part of it, for the slope on the eastern shore from north to south passes by Denia before passing by Almeria. In any case, let us stop at Almeria because it is historically established. It is known that...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...the city of Pechina (Bajana) was the base of the province of Valencia. Pechina is a city established by a group of merchants and Andalusian seafarers who were working between the shores of Andalusia and the Maghreb. They saw that their activity needed support and protection, so they formed a union of merchants, of whom Abu Ubayd mentioned: Al-Karkabi, Abu Aisha, Al-Saqr, and Suhayb. They built a small city next to Tenes on the coast of Algiers and named it "New Tenes" «5» in the year 262 AH / 875 AD. A few years later, a group of merchants landed in the port of Oran [Oran, Algeria] and made it an important seaport in the year 290 / 902, and this group moved its activity to the Moroccan shore, establishing several ports, such as Bejaia [Béjaïa, Algeria], Bone (Annaba) [Annaba, Algeria], and Marsa al-Dajaj «6». When the merchants wished to move their trade to their original homeland in Andalusia, they chose the gulf on which the town of Pechina «7» is located, then it became known as Almeria. This area was a feudal estate in the hands of a group of Yemeni Arabs, left to them by the Emirate of Cordoba, on the condition that they protect the coasts from sea raiders, until it became known as "Arsh al-Yaman" (Throne of Yemen). Then the merchants obtained the right to establish a walled city. The prosperity of Pechina reached its peak in the era of Al-Nasir (died 355 AH / 961 AD). Where...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...he admired Almeria, so he moved the base of the district to it in the year 344 / 955 and established in it large buildings and facilities, until it became one of the major ports of Andalusia. In the author's discussion of the cities of the Upper Frontier facing Christian Spanish lands, we do not see him alluding to the political change that might have occurred to them. He considers them Muslim lands that have to confront the Christian lands. We can decide that this was in the days of strong rule, meaning in the era of Al-Nasir and his successor Al-Hakam II. Islamic influence extended to the mountainous areas to which the Christians had retreated during the conquest, which is what the author mentions at the conclusion of his discussion on the island of Andalusia. The era of Abd al-Rahman al-Nasir and his son Al-Hakam II is considered the Golden Age of Andalusia, where the Christians of Spain submitted and established good relations with the Muslims, to the point that Cordoba became the destination of Christian Spaniards seeking its arbitration in their disputes. It appeared that the movement of the Christian Reconquista had been curbed with no return. Another observation stops us, which is that the author did not talk about Al-Zahra (Madinat al-Zahra), rather he did not mention it. It is known that its construction began in the year 350 AH and finished in the year 365 AH, which leads to the belief that the author wrote his compilation before its establishment.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: After the author finishes with the Andalusian Peninsula, he moves to mention the Christian lands, evidenced by the fact that he left the discussion of Asia Minor previously and placed it within this last section dedicated to Europe, then appended to it the lands of the Khazars, Al-Shash [Tashkent, Uzbekistan], and the non-Muslim Turks. Ibn al-Husayn al-Munajjim begins his discussion about Italy, France, and the lands of the Saqaliba (Slavs), and here reflects the anxiety that prevailed in Europe with the invasions of the Normans and Hungarians. His information here is closely related to the information of the Eastern geographers, and this appears clear in the quotation about Constantinople [Istanbul, Turkey], which is a matter that calls for disappointment. After the impact of the Fatimids on political developments in North Africa was absent from his discussion, we see him again neglecting the Andalusian-Byzantine relations that were active in the fourth Hijri century, except perhaps for a semi-hidden touch of the edge of the subject. While talking about the Byzantines, he says: "Their kingdom is great, and they are people of might and valor, and they fight the Slavs and the Franks, and the Muslims also fight them in the lands of Sham." As for the discussion of the lands of the Khazars and Bulgars, he provides somewhat new information, where we see him closer to what Ibn Fadlan mentioned in his embassy in 309 AH. Now, and in light of what we have presented regarding the absence of some major cities from this dictionary, such as Marrakesh (454 AH), Cairo...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...(359 AH) and Al-Zahra (350-365 AH), we can decide that the author wrote his compilation before 350 AH, and after 344 AH, meaning before the building of Al-Zahra and after Al-Nasir adopted Almeria as the base of the district. As for the manuscript, it is established that it is Yemeni, and we have previously pointed to the relationship between the Yemenis and Andalusia, where the Yemenis landed on the eastern shores of Andalusia, and they were afforded the opportunity to be simultaneously fighters, farmers, and merchants. Whatever confusion in information mars the manuscript, the responsibility does not fall on the author. As for the coordinated information dealing with the Islamic East, it is due to the author's reliance on quoting from previous geographical writings, whereas his information about Africa and the Andalusian Peninsula was more abundant and detailed, despite the author's clear inclination towards brevity in the entirety of his work. Therefore, we tend to say that Ishaq bin al-Husayn al-Munajjim is of Andalusian origin. Meaning that he lived in the Andalusian Peninsula or in the Andalusian commercial colonies on the African shores, and in a final probability, he might be one of the Yemenis who lived in Andalusia and then returned to Yemen, along with the existence of a probability that one of the Yemenis might have transported this manuscript to Yemen. Finally, and at the conclusion of this quick overview, I indicate that I did not wish to detail the relationship between Ishaq bin al-Husayn and those who preceded him, or those who...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhurah fi Kul Makan
text: ...followed him. I have indicated in the footnotes the places where he meets with them or quotes from them. As for who quoted from him, we have indicated at the beginning of this research Al-Idrisi and Ibn Khaldun. As for the relationship between our author and Abu Ubayd al-Bakri, its place is other than this place, and other than this occasion. And Allah is the Guardian of success. Beirut [Beirut, Lebanon]. Fahmi Sa'ad. January 1988.

text: The book "Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan" (Coral Hills in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere), authored by the Sheikh Ishaq bin al-Husayn al-Munajjim, may Allah cause him to dwell in the gardens of Paradise by the right of Muhammad and his family, and may Allah bless the Prophet and his family.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
Mention of the Honored City of Mecca [Makkah, Saudi Arabia]
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
Ishaq bin al-Husayn, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him, said: We only mentioned Mecca [Makkah, Saudi Arabia] before other lands because it is the Sacred House of Allah, and the first house placed on earth. Its distance from the line of the beginning of the earth is sixty-nine degrees. A degree is thirty-six miles and two-thirds of a mile, and likewise for every degree we mention regarding other cities. Similarly, «1» when we mention the distance from the western line [Prime Meridian of antiquity], we only mean the beginning of the earth, and likewise the distance from the Equator, we only mean the distance from the line of the middle of the earth, in reality, regarding the inhabited part of the earth, because the inhabited part of the earth is very small. Based on what is mentioned regarding the dimensions of cities from the western line and the Equator, one can know some of them from others, and what is between them of...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: distances, by way of calculation, and knowing that is a great science. So the distance of Mecca [Makkah, Saudi Arabia] from the western line is sixty-seven degrees, and that in miles is four thousand four hundred and twenty-two miles. [And its distance is twenty-three degrees, and it is said: twenty-one] «2» from the Equator in the direction of the north. Most of the cities that we will mention after this are only [in] the northern direction, because the inhabited part of the earth is only the northern quarter which follows the North Pole and Banat Na'sh (Ursa Major). Mecca is in the belly of a valley «3» between mountains and valleys. Among its great mountains are: Abu Qubays, al-Muhassab, and Thabir. It was the abode of Adam, peace be upon him. The [Black Stone] «4» remained there until the Flood occurred. Then Allah the Exalted commanded Ibrahim [Abraham], the Friend, to build it. [Abu Ja'far] al-Mansur «5» increased the building of the house of the Kaaba...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: [And the beginning of his work was in Muharram of the year one hundred and thirty-seven, and the completion of it was in Dhu al-Hijjah of the year forty. Then his son al-Mahdi expanded it in the year] «6» one hundred and sixty-four. The length of the Mosque is four hundred cubits, and its width is three hundred «7». It has twenty-three doors. From al-Safa to al-Marwa is four hundred and forty cubits, and the height of the House is twenty-eight cubits «8». It is the Qibla for all countries. So the Qibla of the people of Kufa [Kufa, Iraq], Baghdad [Baghdad, Iraq], and what...

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: was with it, on one line, is the Levantine Corner which is between the Door and the Stone. And the Qibla of the people of Basra [Basra, Iraq] and what aligns with it of the cities is the door of the Kaaba. And the Qibla of the people of Yemen [Yemen] is the Yemeni Corner. And the Qibla of the people of India [India] and Sindh [Pakistan] is the Black Stone. And the Qibla of the people of al-Sham [Syria/Levant] is the door of the Kaaba. And the people of al-Hijaz [Saudi Arabia] are likewise, except that it is slightly deviated. And the people of Yemen face towards the people of Armenia [Armenia].
