text:
The City of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and grant them peace
It is the place of emigration «1» of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and his family and grant them peace, and the place of his settlement. In it is his grave, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and the graves of his companions. He named it Taybah, because from its direction you find the scent of perfume (Tayyib) from its side for many miles. Its distance from the western line is one hundred and sixty degrees, and that in miles is [seven thousand five hundred and fifty-six]. «2» Its distance from the Equator is twenty-five degrees, and that in miles is one thousand six hundred and fifty miles. The City [Medina, Saudi Arabia] is on level ground, its soil is noble and majestic. It has two mountains: one of them is Uhud, and the other mountain is Radwa.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: Its people are from the Emigrants (Muhajirun), the Helpers (Ansar), the Successors (Tabi'un), and the tribes of the Arabs. It has four valleys «3» whose water comes at the time of rains, and the greatest of them is Wadi al-Aqiq. Most of its wealth is palm trees, which is the livelihood of its people «4». The Great Sea [Red Sea] is at a distance of three days [from it] «5». In it is the Mosque of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and his family and grant them peace, and his pulpit and his grave, may Allah bless him and his family and grant them peace. The Mosque's length is three hundred cubits, and its width is two hundred cubits «6». Its columns are three hundred columns «7». As for the Noble Pulpit, Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan added six steps to it «8». And there is the Rawdah (Garden), which is one of the gardens of Paradise «9», between the elevated Grave and the Pulpit.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
Mention of Bayt al-Maqdis (Jerusalem), Aelia «1»
It is one of the great ancient cities [Jerusalem, Palestine/Israel]. In it are the graves of the prophets, Allah's blessings be upon them, and their traces «2». Its distance from the western line is fifty-six degrees, and that in miles is three thousand six hundred and ninety-six miles. Its distance from the Equator in the northern direction is thirty-two degrees, and that in miles is two thousand one hundred and twelve miles. It is majestic, and its water is from rains. Outside of it are gardens, vineyards, farms, trees, and olives «3». In it is the Palm Tree of Maryam under which she gave birth to Isa [Jesus] [peace be upon him] «4». In it is the Mihrab (Sanctuary) of Dawud [David], peace be upon him «5».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: In it is the Suspended Rock. In it is a great mountain, from which Isa [Jesus] [peace be upon him] was raised to the sky. In it is a very great mosque, which is the greatest of the mosques of the world, and in it is the Gate of Mercy. Every nation makes pilgrimage to it and venerates it, and in it are prayer niches (Miharib).

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
Mention of the City of Baghdad
We only returned to the mention of the city of Baghdad [Baghdad, Iraq], after presenting what was necessary to present, because it is the origin of cities, the best of them in construction, and the finest of them in air/climate. It is in the middle of the Fourth Clime, which is the most cherished of climes, and its people are the greatest of people in varieties of intellect and understanding. Abu Ja'far al-Mansur, from the Banu Abbas, built it, and he began that in the beginning, in the year one hundred and forty-one «1». He transported builders, skilled workers, and craftsmen from all countries to it. He made it circular, and expanded its gardens «2» and its alleys. Those who took charge of that from the people of calculation and engineers were:

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: Al-Hajjaj bin Artah the Calculator «3», al-Tabari, and Ibrahim al-Fazari. It has paths «4» with gates; in its circumference is twenty cubits. It has four gates, and between each gate is five thousand cubits: the Gate of Kufa, the Gate of Basra, the Gate of Khurasan, and the Gate of al-Sham [Syria]. On every gate is a casing of iron; only a group of men can close it. For every gate of them is a vestibule, and on every gate of them is a great dome adorned with gold. Around the Palace are the houses of the children of the Banu Abbas and the people of service. The Palace is in the middle of the city, and to its side is the Great Mosque. It is between the Tigris River and the Euphrates. In ancient times, there were a thousand mosques and twenty thousand baths «5» in it. Its distance from the western line is seventy degrees, and that in miles is four thousand six hundred and twenty miles.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: Its distance from the Equator in the north is thirty-three degrees, and that in miles is two thousand one hundred and seventy-eight miles. Al-Mansur had transported palm trees and trees to it, so they sprouted and grew in a short period, and that is due to the goodness of its water and the temperateness of its air. Likewise, he transported marble, columns, and craftsmen from every land to it. He ordered the people of service that each one of them should take a plot and build, so they took plots «6» and increased the building, and it rose in the shortest period. Its orchards are watered by the water of the Tigris and the Euphrates in canals. Al-Mansur's residence before that was in the city of al-Anbar [Al-Anbar, Iraq], which «7» al-Saffah, the first of the Caliphs of the Banu Abbas, had settled in.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
Mention of the City of Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra)
As for the city of Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra, Iraq], it was built by al-Mu'tasim bin Harun al-Rashid «1». Before that, it was a desert with no buildings in it. In ancient times, there was a monastery for Christians in it. The reason for its construction was that al-Mu'tasim used to acquire many Turks. When the Caliphate passed «2» to him, he persisted in seeking them. Those Turks, when they rode animals, would gallop and collide with people, so the mob would leap upon them and kill some of them and beat some of them. That became heavy upon al-Mu'tasim, so he went out from Baghdad [Iraq] and sought a place to dig a river [canal] in, until he reached al-Qatul. He began the building and allotted land to the commanders, the scribes, and the people, so they built on al-Qatul and the Tigris.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: Then he went to the location of Surra Man Ra'a [Samarra, Iraq], bought the monastery, and wrote to bring in laborers, builders, people of professions, and all craftsmen. Then he allotted the fiefs to the commanders, the scribes, and the people, and he separated the fiefs of the Turks from the fiefs of all the people. He ordered the building of mosques and markets. He bought slave girls for the Turks and married them to them, and forbade them from marrying or intermarrying with any of the Muwalladun (locally born/mixed heritage), and he established fixed provisions for the slave girls. When he finished the building, he dug rivers from the Tigris, and brought palm trees from Baghdad [Iraq], Basra [Iraq], and the rest of the Sawad [Fertile alluvial land of Iraq], al-Jazira [Upper Mesopotamia], al-Sham [Syria/Levant], and all other lands. Al-Mu'tasim built edifices and palaces, and placed a palace in every garden, containing sitting rooms, pools, and squares. Al-Mu'tasim Billah died in the year two hundred and twenty-seven. Harun al-Wathiq bin al-Mu'tasim built the Haruni Palace in it. Al-Mutawakkil bin al-Mu'tasim took charge and settled in the Haruni, settled his son Muhammad al-Muntasir in al-Jawsaq, settled his son Ibrahim al-Mu'ayyad in al-Matirah, and settled his son al-Mu'tazz in Balkuwara. Al-Mutawakkil built al-Ja'fariyya and the Congregational Mosque] «3».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
[Mention of the City of Kufa]
[It is in the Third Clime. Its distance from the western line is sixty-nine and a half degrees. And from the Equator is thirty-one and two-thirds degrees. It is on the Euphrates [River]. Its air is healthy and its water is sweet. Kufa [Kufa, Iraq] is the great city of Iraq [Iraq], the dome of Islam, and the abode of emigration for the Muslims. It contains plans for the tribes of the Arabs. In Kufa is the grave of the Commander of the Faithful Ali, Allah's blessings be upon him. Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas established it as a garrison city] «2» in the caliphate of Ibn al-Khattab. It is the first city established by the Muslims after Basra.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
Mention of the City of Basra
It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the western line is sixty-four degrees, and that in miles is four thousand eight hundred and eighty-four miles. Basra [Basra, Iraq] is the city of the world, the base of Iraq [Iraq], and the season of merchants. It is elongated, two farsakhs (leagues) in length by one farsakh in width. Utbah bin Ghazwan «1», one of the first Emigrants, established it as a garrison city in the caliphate of Umar bin al-Khattab, in the year fourteen of the Hijra. He is the one who conquered al-Ubulla «2».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: And from it in the northern direction is a river that comes from al-Batihah [Marshes of Iraq], at a distance of three farsakhs. It has sweet water «3». The two cities «4» of Kufa [Kufa, Iraq] and Basra [Basra, Iraq] are on one line, and between them is a sea [waterway] of seven days' journey. In the middle of the distance from it is the city of Wasit [Wasit, Iraq].

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the city of Wasit [Wasit, Iraq]. It is in the fourth clime. Its distance from the Equator is like the distance of the cities of Basra [Basra, Iraq] and Kufa [Kufa, Iraq]. Its distance from the line of the West (Prime Meridian of the ancients) is seventy-one degrees, which in miles is four thousand six hundred and thirty-six miles. It was named Wasit only because it is situated in the middle (Wasat) between Kufa [Kufa, Iraq] and Basra [Basra, Iraq]. [It] is not ancient; it was built by Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf, the governor of Abd al-Malik bin Marwan. The reason for its construction was that Abd al-Malik sent soldiers from the people of...

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: ...Sham (Syria) to Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf, to be of assistance to him in wars. The people of Iraq became distressed by them, because they used to stay with them in the houses and look continuously at their women. They complained of this to Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, so he ordered Al-Hajjaj to build a city for the people of Sham to which he would transfer them.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the city of Abadan [Abadan, Iran] in Ahwaz [Ahvaz, Iran]. It is in the fourth clime. Its distance from the line of the West is seventy-five degrees, which in miles is four thousand nine hundred and fifty miles. Its distance from the Equator is thirty-one degrees, which in miles is two thousand two hundred and thirty-six miles. It is on the coast of the Sea of Iraq, connected to the Great Green Sea. It is populated with its people, and in it are the Murabitun (garrison soldiers) and ascetics. The Abadani mats are made there. Near it, the Euphrates falls into the Great Sea.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the city of Siraf [Bandar Siraf, Iran]. It is in the third clime. Its distance from the line of the West is seventy-nine degrees, which in miles is [five] thousand two hundred and twenty-four miles. It is on the coast of the Sea of Iraq, among the districts of Fars [Fars Province, Iran]. It is a majestic city, a pleasant spot, where governors stay. It has spaciousness in its houses, and wondrous orchards containing aromatic plants and varieties of trees. Its people drink from springs that come from a mountain. Most of its inhabitants are Persian nobles (Ajam Ashraf). Its districts were conquered by Abdullah bin Amir bin Kurayz during the caliphate of Uthman bin Affan.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the city of Sanaa [Sanaa, Yemen], may Allah the Almighty protect it. It is a city in Yemen, and its capital; there is none greater than it therein. It is mountainous and land-based, with temperate air and good water. Trees bear fruit for them there, and they harvest crops twice a year, because they have two winters and two summers. This is the [case] for every land whose distance from the Equator is less than fourteen degrees. It is in the first clime. Its houses are painted with red and green, and its carpets are spread out, awaiting the rains at known times that do not vary. [Thus] it rains on them for one month in the summer and one month in the winter. And the most that...

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: ...occurs is in the evening/afternoon. So they hurry to return to their homes. The floodwater sweeps out all the dirt that is in it, because it is paved, and it comes to their farms in canals. It has a wall and a street overlooking a valley. In its congregational mosque is the grave of a prophet among the prophets. They have many fruits. Fine garments and wondrous vessels are made there. They are crafters of gem stones and boring of pearls. They gather in the mosque to read sciences and the Dear Book (Quran), may Allah benefit via it, Amen.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the city of Aden [Aden, Yemen]. It is in the first clime. Its distance from the line of the West is sixty-five degrees, which in miles is eight hundred and twenty miles. It has two summers and two winters. It is intensely hot because the sun passes over their heads twice a year. That is the [case] for all lands that are in the first clime. Aden is on the coast of the Great Sea. In it are fishermen, and they extract pearls from the sea. In it are cisterns and rivers. Its people resemble the Arabs. It cannot be entered except from one side.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: It is large and populated. There are no trees or crops in it. Their livelihood is from fish. Fine garments and wondrous vessels are made there.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: The city of Oman [Oman]. It is in the second clime. Its distance from the line of the West is eighty-four degrees, which in miles is five thousand five hundred and forty miles. Its distance from the Equator is thirty degrees, which in miles is one thousand seven hundred and eighty miles. It is on the sea coast. It is fortified and has iron gates. In it are flowing waters, populated markets, orchards, palm trees, bananas, and all other fruits. It has wheat, barley, and rice. Its territories are vast, eighty parasangs by the like, plains...

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: ...and mountains. In it is sugar cane. On the heads of its people are long locks of hair (Jumam), and on the heads of the nobles are tall caps (Qalanis).

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: The city of Saba [Marib, Yemen]. It is in the second clime. Its distance from the line of the West is sixty-five degrees, which in miles is four thousand two hundred and ninety miles. Its distance from the Equator is seventeen degrees, which in miles is one thousand and eighty miles. In it are mines of gold. It is the city of Bilqis, and in it was her throne. Her traces remain in the pillars that were upon it, until they were cut off in the time of Solomon son of David, peace be upon them both. Near it is the city of Ma'rib [Marib, Yemen]. It used to have abundant blessings and trees. A woman would go out with her basket on her head and her spindle in her hand...

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: ...walking among the trees, which were continuous and extended, and she would not return except that the [basket] was filled with fruits falling without picking or harvesting. But they disbelieved, so Allah sent upon them the flood of Arim (the dam); it would demolish the dam by night what they used to repair by day. It is the one Allah mentioned in His Dear Book: "There was for Saba, in their dwelling place, a sign: two gardens."

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Hadhramaut [Hadhramaut, Yemen]. It is in the first clime. Its distance from the line of the West is seventy-one degrees, which in miles is four thousand six hundred and eighty. Its distance from the Equator is twelve degrees, which in miles is seven hundred and ninety-two miles. It is from the lands of Yemen. The lands of Hadhramaut are numerous and continuous, possessing palm trees, trees, and farms. Its people are many tribes, and they judge by the rulings of the Commander of the Faithful, Ali bin Abi Talib, and Fatimah the daughter of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon them both. They say: "In every creed, there is no judgment except the judgment of Allah and His messenger." Between Aden [Aden, Yemen] and Hadhramaut are deserts and great mountains, possessing trees...

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: ...and in it are monkeys that persist in the vineyards and trees, and they hunt them with dogs. Most of their trees are palm trees. Alum (or vitriol) becomes a river from flowing springs, then it solidifies and becomes stones. Near Oman [Oman] is the city of Socotra [Socotra, Yemen], and in it is the Socotran ambergris. The people of Yemen are a people of acumen and intellect. Allah Almighty and Majestic said: "Then depart from the place from where [all] the people depart."

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: The city of Bahrain [Bahrain/Eastern Arabia]. It is in the second clime. It is in the beginning of Yemen. It is a majestic city. The water in it is near (the surface), dug by hand. In it are palm trees, pomegranates, citrons, and figs. They do not walk except in the early morning and evening due to the heat of the land. In it are great mountains of sand, driven by the winds, and perhaps they rise over their towns. There used to be a road between Bahrain and Oman [Oman] in the past, but the mountains of sand cut it off, so one cannot reach Oman from Bahrain except by sea. In it are two great mountains, and between the sea and them is a journey of ten days. Hajar [Al-Hasa, Saudi Arabia] is the capital of Bahrain. Its people are Arabs, and they are the ones who came as a delegation to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and his family and grant them peace.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Taif [Taif, Saudi Arabia] and Al-Yamama [Al-Yamama/Al-Kharj, Saudi Arabia]. They are in the second clime along with Mecca [Makkah, Saudi Arabia] on one line. Their distance from the Equator is equal. Taif is closer to Mecca than Al-Yamama. From Mecca to Taif is a journey of two days, and likewise between Taif and Al-Yamama. Their people are Arabs. The capital is Hajar al-Yamamah [Riyadh region, Saudi Arabia]. It has abundant fertility and goodness, and most of its trees are palm trees.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: The city of Damascus [Damascus, Syria]. It is in the fourth clime. Its distance from the Equator is thirty-three degrees, and its distance from the line of the West is sixty degrees. It is an ancient city; there is none like it in the land of Islam or the land of the Romans (Byzantium). It has a wall of stone, and its circumference is twelve miles. Abu Ubaydah bin al-Jarrah conquered it by treaty, and they possess the treaty document. In it is the grave of Yahya bin Zakariya (John the Baptist) in a church called Al-Qasqar. In it is the River Orontes [Orontes River/Barada River], upon which are the buildings, estates, and orchards.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: In it are many springs coming from mountain channels, entering every direction. Its people are a folk from the non-Arabs (Ajam). In it also are a folk from the Arabs. Its mosque is one of the wonders of the world in beauty and perfection.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the city of Aleppo [Aleppo, Syria] as well. It is in the fourth clime, close to Antioch [Antakya, Turkey]. The governors of Al-Awasim (The Border Fortresses) stay there. It is populated with its people, and in it are the homes of Banu Hashim. Its distance from the line of the West is sixty-three degrees.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the city of Tiberias [Tiberias, Israel]. Its distance from the line of the West is fifty-eight degrees, and from the Equator thirty-two degrees. It is the city of Jordan. It is below mountains on a great lake, from which a river exits. In it is a hot spring from which channels exit to the baths; they do not need to heat them. Amr bin al-Aas conquered it in the year fourteen. In it is the Pit of Joseph, peace be upon him.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Asqalan [Ashkelon, Israel]
It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the Equator is thirty-three degrees. It is on the coast of the Levantine Sea [Mediterranean Sea] «1». It is paved with marble and has many markets. It has palm trees, and its water is from springs. Ibrahim [Abraham], peace be upon him, was there, and in it are wondrous ruins of Namrud bin Kan'an [Nimrod son of Canaan]. It is between the borders of Egypt [Egypt] and al-Sham [Syria/Levant] «2».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Tarsus [Tarsus, Turkey]
It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the western line is fifty-eight degrees. And from the Equator is thirty-six degrees. Al-Rashid built it in the year one hundred and seventy «1». In it is a flowing river «2» that comes from the land of the Romans [Byzantine Empire] and cuts through its middle. Its people are a mixture of people. The land tax (Kharaj) of Damascus [Damascus, Syria] and its districts reaches six hundred thousand dinars «3», and the land tax of Tarsus is three hundred thousand dinars.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of al-Mosul [Mosul, Iraq]
It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the western line is sixty-nine degrees. It is in the western province of the Tigris [River]. Muhammad bin Marwan bin al-Hakam «1» built it when he governed al-Jazira [Upper Mesopotamia] during the caliphate of his brother Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, and he moved people to it. It has many rivers «2», and it is noble and great. The land tax of al-Mosul «3» reaches six thousand thousand [six million], and most of its people are from Hamadan.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: The road from al-Mosul to Azerbaijan [Azerbaijan/Northwestern Iran] is a month. Azerbaijan «4» is a great city [region], having districts and works. In it is a Fire House [Temple] that has been maintained for the Majus [Zoroastrians], may Allah the Exalted curse them.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Hamadhan [Hamadan, Iran]
It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the western line is seventy-three degrees, and from the Equator is thirty-six degrees. Hamadhan is a vast land with many provinces and districts «1». It was conquered in the year twenty-three, and its wealth remained in the treasury of Basra. The drinking water of its people is from springs and valleys that flow in winter and summer. From Hamadhan to Nahavand [Nahavand, Iran] is two stages. It is a noble city where the gathering of the Persians «3» used to be.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Isfahan [Isfahan, Iran]
It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the western line is seventy-five degrees. It is a noble city, and its people are a mixture of people, most of them being Ajam [Persians] «1». It has waters from valleys and springs «2». Qutayba «3» said: Abu Musa al-Ash'ari conquered Isfahan by force in the time of Umar bin al-Khattab; it was conquered in the year twenty-three «4». The amount of its land tax is ten thousand thousand [ten million] dirhams «5». Anushirvan, the King of the Persians «6», was born there.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of al-Rayy [Rayy, Tehran, Iran]
It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the western line is seventy-four degrees. From the Equator, it is thirty-four degrees. It is a noble city. Its people are a mixture of people, from the Persians, Arabs, and Turks «1». Its name is al-Mahdiyya «2», because al-Mahdi settled in it during the caliphate of al-Mansur, and al-Rashid was born there. Qarzah bin Ka'b al-Ansari conquered it in the caliphate of Umar bin al-Khattab in the year twenty-four «3». Its people drink from springs and great rivers coming from the lands of Daylam [Gilan, Iran]. It has many trees «4».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
Mention of the City of Hulwan [Sarpol-e Zahab, Iran]
It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the Equator is thirty-four degrees. From the western line, it is seventy-two degrees. It is a noble city. Its people are a mixture of Arabs, Persians, and Kurds «1». It was conquered in the days of Umar bin al-Khattab. In it are ruins of the Kings of the Persians, and in it are rivers, some above others. Between Hulwan and Baghdad is the city of Tabaristan «2».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Tabaristan [Mazandaran, Iran] «1»
It is in the works of Khurasan [Greater Khorasan], a great kingdom. It is a land of many fortresses, fortified by valleys «2». Its people are the nobles of the Ajam [Persians] and the sons of their kings. They are the best of people in faces (appearance) «3». It is mentioned that Yazdegerd left his slave girls and daughters there at the time of the conquest over the Persians, so the people of Tabaristan married them «4». Sa'id bin al-As conquered it by peace treaty in the time of Uthman. And Umar bin al-Ala conquered it «5» in the year [one hundred and] fifty-seven.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
Mention of the City of Jurjan [Gorgan, Iran]
It is in the Fifth Clime. Its distance from the western line is eighty degrees, and from the Equator is thirty-nine degrees. It is among the cities of Khurasan up to the river al-Ayli «1». It was conquered in the caliphate of Muawiyah bin Abi Sufyan «2», then its people apostatized from Islam, until Yazid bin al-Muhallab conquered it in the caliphate of Sulayman bin Abd al-Malik. It is great, and its land tax reaches ten thousand thousand [ten million] dinars «3».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: In it, good wood is made from Khalanj (Tree heath) «4» and others, and varieties of silk garments. It has the great Bakhati [Bactrian] camels «5», and it has many palm trees. Between it and al-Rayy [Tehran, Iran] is nine stages.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
Mention of the City of Nishapur [Neyshabur, Iran]
It is in the Fifth Clime. Its distance from the western line is eighty-two degrees, and from the Equator is thirty-nine degrees. Nishapur is a vast land with many districts «1». Abdullah bin Amir bin Kurayz conquered it in the caliphate of Uthman bin Affan, [may Allah be pleased with] him, in the year thirty. Its people are a mixture of Arabs and Ajam [Persians] «2». Its drinking source is from valleys and springs, and its land tax is five thousand thousand [five million] dirhams «3». It is from the works of Khurasan, and fine garments of silk and cotton «4» are made there.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: [Tus] Among its districts «1» is the city of Tus [Tus, Iran]. In it are a people from the Arabs, but most of its people are Ajam [Persians] «2». The Commander of the Faithful al-Rashid died there, and his grave is there «3». Its distance from the western line is eighty-three degrees, and from the Equator is thirty-nine degrees. Its land tax enters into the land tax of Nishapur «4».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
Mention of the City of Marw [Merv, Turkmenistan]
It is in the Fifth Clime. Its distance from the western line is eighty-five degrees, and from the Equator is thirty-eight degrees. It «1» is among the most glorious districts of Khurasan. Hatim bin al-Nu'man al-Bahili conquered it in the caliphate of Uthman in the year thirty-one «2». Its people are nobles from the Ajam [Persians], and in it are a people of the Arabs from al-Azd «3». The governors of Khurasan stay there «4».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: Its people drink from springs of valleys «5». The Marwi garments of cotton are made there. From the city of Marw to the city of Sarakhs [Sarakhs, Iran/Turkmenistan border] is three stages.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Sarakhs [Sarakhs, Iran]
It is in the Fifth Clime. Its distance from the western line is eighty-four degrees. And from the Equator is thirty-eight degrees. It is a noble land and a great noble city. It is wilderness, mountains, and sands «1». In it are mixtures of people. Abdullah bin Hatim al-Sulami «2» conquered it in the caliphate of Uthman. The drinking water of its people is from wells, and there is no river or spring in it «3». Its land tax is one thousand thousand [one million] dirhams, and it is from the districts of Khurasan «4». From Nishapur to Herat [Herat, Afghanistan] is ten stages, every stage a full Barid (post distance) «5».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Herat [Herat, Afghanistan]
It is in the Fifth Clime. It is one of the largest lands of Khurasan «1». It is populated, and its people have the best faces among people. Al-Ahnaf bin Qays conquered it in the caliphate of Uthman bin Affan. Its people are nobles from the Ajam [Persians], and in it are a people from the Arabs. The drinking water of its people is from springs and valleys. Its land tax is included in the land tax of Khurasan «2». From Herat to Sijistan [Sistan, Iran/Afghanistan] is three stages.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Kirman [Kerman, Iran] «1»
It is in the Third Clime. Its distance from the western line is ninety degrees. And from the Equator is thirty degrees. It is great and noble, having districts and provinces, and its waters are few «2». Abd al-Rahman bin Samura bin Habib conquered it, and he made peace with its people for two thousand thousand [two million] dirhams «3» in the caliphate of Uthman. The best of its works is the city of Kirman which is next to al-Sind [Pakistan].

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Khwarazm [Khiva/Urgench, Uzbekistan/Turkmenistan] «1»
It is in the Sixth Clime. Its distance from the western line is ninety-one degrees. And from the Equator is forty-two degrees. It is among the cities of Khurasan. It is great. A great dam used to surround it and its works, but most of it was destroyed «2». It is in the middle of a desert and sands. Between it and Sijistan [Sistan] is a stage. It is known as Jurjan «3».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Sijistan [Sistan, Iran/Afghanistan] «1»
It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the western line is sixty-four degrees, and from the Equator is thirty-two degrees. It is a noble land having many districts, comparable in districts to the districts of Khurasan «2». It is isolated yet connected to the lands of al-Sind [Pakistan] «3», and the road to it is in deserts and wastelands. The first of the governors to settle in it was Ma'n bin Zaida al-Shaybani «4». Then it acted hypocritically many times. It was conquered in the caliphate of Uthman bin Affan first, and in all his days its ownership continued by way of peace treaty. When Abu Ja'far al-Mansur of the Banu Abbas assumed the Caliphate...

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: spent it on the administration of Khurasan [Khorasan region, Iran/Afghanistan/Turkmenistan], and appointed Ma'n bin Za'idah al-Shaybani as its governor. And Khurasan, its land tax (kharaj) is ten thousand thousand (ten million).

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Balkh [Balkh, Afghanistan]. It is in the Fifth Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is eighty-eight degrees. From the Equator, thirty-seven degrees. It has many cities and districts, and it has forty-nine cemeteries. It is the capital of Greater Khurasan. It is great and of high esteem, has a wall, and has twelve gates. It is in the middle of the lands of Khurasan, containing palaces and homes of the Barmakids, due to the length of their governorship over the works of Khurasan during the caliphate of Banu al-Abbas. On the eastern side of Balkh is a great river.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Bukhara [Bukhara, Uzbekistan]. It is in the Fifth Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is eighty-seven degrees. It is a vast land, which has never ceased to be of strong defense and fortification. Sa'id bin Uthman bin Affan conquered it in the time of Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan, then it turned hypocritical (rebelled), and was conquered in the caliphate of Yazid bin Mu'awiyah, then it resisted until Qutaybah bin Muslim came to it in the time of Al-Walid bin Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, so he conquered it. Its land tax is one thousand thousand (one million) dirhams. From Bukhara to the lands of India is seven stages.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Samarqand [Samarkand, Uzbekistan]. It is in the Fifth Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is eighty-nine degrees, and from the Equator thirty-six degrees. It is among the most majestic of lands and the greatest, the most unassailable, and having the most men. It is at the throat of the lands of the Turks. It turned hypocritical after it was conquered, then Qutaybah bin Muslim conquered it in the time of Al-Walid, and made a peace treaty with its king. [It has] a great river coming from the lands of the Turks called Asaf.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Alexandria [Alexandria, Egypt]. It is in the West of the land of Egypt. Its distance from the line of the West is fifty-one degrees, and from the Equator, thirty degrees. It is one of the wonders of the lands. In it is an amazing structure; it is mentioned that it was built in three hundred years, and that its people remained for seventy years not walking in it during the day except with black rags on their faces, out of fear for their eyesight due to the intensity of its whiteness. Upon its houses is a crab of marble, and the Lighthouse (Pharos) is upon four pillars, and its height is three hundred cubits. The walls of the city are of marble, as is its wall.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: In it is a dome that belonged to Pharaoh, and in it is the palace of Solomon son of David, peace be upon him; it has fallen into ruin and its ruins remain. In it is a pillar that rotates for all time. In it are ribats (fortified hospices) on the sea coast where worshippers and strangers stay. In ancient times, upon its lighthouse was a large mirror made by the wise men, by which one could look upon Constantinople [Istanbul, Turkey] and the lands of the Romans (Byzantines), until a trick was used to bring it down, so no one was able to restore it.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Dimyat [Damietta, Egypt]. It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is fifty-three degrees. It is on the coast of the Levantine Sea. Its people are rich, and they have no work except the making of fine garments, the like of which is not made in other lands, due to the mildness of its air. Because the sea surrounds it from the north side, and the canals of the Nile separate upon it. From Dimyat, one rides to the lands of the Romans. The island of Cyprus [Cyprus] and the island of Crete [Crete, Greece] are near it in the sea. Flour and fruits are carried from it to the harbor of Dimyat. Near the city of Dimyat on the sea is the city of Tinnis, and it is on the same line with it.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Tinnis [Tennis, Egypt]. It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is fifty-four degrees, and from the Equator, thirty-one degrees. It is large, and most of its people are Christians; they work on the Sultan's embroidery, containing varieties of fine garments. The sea surrounds it, and there is no way to it except on boats. It has a wall of stone, which the waves of the sea strike. Its water is salty for six months of the year, but when the Nile floods, its waters become fresh, due to the reaching of the Nile's flood into the canals. Its people are rich, and fish are plentiful there; they come out to the coast without being fished.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Misr [Cairo, Egypt]. It is in the Third Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is fifty-four degrees, and from the Equator twenty-nine degrees. It is great; its length along the Nile is parasangs. It has many estates in the Upper Sa'id, opposite the lands of Nubia. In it are the two Pyramids; their height is one hundred cubits. They are of rock, and in them food used to be gathered in the days of Yusuf, peace be upon him. In some of its baths is a girl of marble, water flows over her private part; it is said: She is a slave girl from the slave girls of Pharaoh.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Upon the Nile is a structure built of rock, containing signs of outflow regarding its increase and decrease. A group has been entrusted with it to monitor it; so if it goes out, it waters all their estates and farms. The Nile comes from the lands of the Sudan; its exit is from the Mountain of the Moon, behind the Equator, and hardly anyone can reach it. In Misr, there are palm trees, bananas, and sugar cane. Near the Muqattam Mountain is their cemetery.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Madyan [Al-Bad', Saudi Arabia]. It is in the Third Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is sixty-one degrees, and from the Equator, twenty-nine degrees. It is between the borders of Al-Sham and the borders of Egypt. It is the city of Shu'ayb, peace be upon him. In it is his cave where he used to shelter with his sheep. In it are many mountains, and in them are caves and caverns under the earth, containing decaying bones, upon which are established structures. They are the people of Shu'ayb, when Allah the Almighty destroyed them, so "the Blast seized them," and they entered the caverns under the earth so as not to hear the Blast, but they all died.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: And in Madyan is the Well from which Musa, peace be upon him, drew water, and [upon it] is a built grave.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of Ayn al-Shams [Heliopolis/Cairo, Egypt]. It is in the Third Clime. Its distance from the Equator is thirty degrees, and from the line of the West fifty-four degrees. It was the city of Pharaoh, and the site of his kingship. In it are amazing traces and buildings, and in it are pillars, statues, and inscriptions. There is a river set in a rock, around which is a chair of marble; [Pharaoh] used to sit upon it with his slave girls. The river used to flow with wine and honey. In it is an image of marble; it is mentioned that she was the hair-comber of Pharaoh's wife, [and it is] a transformed image. In it are two idols of stone; one of them weeps, and the other laughs.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Al-Qulzum, which is Suez [Suez, Egypt]. It is in the Third Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is fifty-six degrees, and from the Equator twenty-eight degrees. It is on the Sea of Al-Qulzum. From it, one crosses the sea [to] Mecca [Makkah, Saudi Arabia] and the Hijaz from there at the city of Jeddah [Jeddah, Saudi Arabia]. Between Misr (Cairo) and the city of Al-Qulzum is a journey of three days in deserts; there is no habitation in it nor property. It is the land of Al-Tih (The Wandering) in which the Children of Israel wandered in this place. The Sea of Al-Qulzum is the one Allah the Almighty split for Musa bin Imran, peace be upon him, at the time of his crossing with the Children of Israel in the sea, and his trace is in it. That place is [fearsome and not traversed]. Rarely do ships remain safe in it.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: In it is a bridge. And sleeping places for the monks. Then one ascends the mountain on six thousand five hundred steps; at its top are a church and amazing traces. It is the one which "He made level" when He, Mighty and Majestic, manifested to Musa bin Imran. The city of Al-Qulzum is a mine for merchants, and in it is the harbor for ships from the lands of India.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Tarablus [Tripoli, Libya]. It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is thirty-six degrees, and from the Equator thirty-four degrees. It is on the Levantine Sea. In it is a great harbor, containing a thousand ships. Its people are from Quraysh; Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan transferred them to it. It has fig and olive trees. It has many villages. Between it and Al-Qayrawan [Kairouan, Tunisia] is a journey of six days, and between it and Sirte [Sirte, Libya] in the east are sands and deserts with no water in them. The city of Sirte is large; it has a congregational mosque and a small flowing river

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: and palm trees. It is near the Levantine Sea. Between it and Ajdabiya is a journey of three days. Ajdabiya [Ajdabiya, Libya] is in sands; there are no trees in it except the Arak. These cities are in the first passage between Al-Qayrawan and Misr (Egypt). The city of Ayla [Aqaba, Jordan] contains a group of Jews; in their hands is a covenant of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and grant them peace, in the handwriting of Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Al-Qayrawan [Kairouan, Tunisia]. It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is thirty-one degrees. It is the capital of Ifriqiya and its fortress. It is large and majestic, not ancient; it was built in the caliphate of Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan. That is because when Mu'awiyah appointed Uqbah bin Nafi' al-Fihri al-Qurashi over the land of Egypt and Ifriqiya, he laid out the city of Al-Qayrawan. Before that, it was a thicket and a forest that could not be sought, nor entered due to the large number of predatory beasts, lions, and snakes. He prayed to Allah against them, so nothing remained of them but that it went out fleeing from it, to the point that the predatory beasts and lions were carrying their young in their mouths and with their paws. So he was named Abu al-Rabi'.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Near the gate of the city is a great pool in which ships sail. In it is a congregational mosque. In it are two pillars that exude water every Friday before the rising of the sun. The King of the Romans had sent for them to take them, and offered monies for them, but it was not accepted from him.

book_title: Hills of Coral in Mentioning Famous Cities Everywhere
text: Mention of the City of Tahert [Tiaret, Algeria]. It is in the Fourth Clime. Its distance from the line of the West is twenty-two degrees, and from the Equator, thirty-three degrees. It is the capital of the people of the Berbers. It is near the Levantine Sea. In it is a congregational mosque, and it has three gates. It is among the grandest of the lands of the Berbers. What is around it are sands, deserts, and settlements. The dwelling of the Berbers is in tents, and they move from place to place, similar to the action of the Arabs. They are a people of harshness and ignorance; they fight one another. Ishaq bin al-Husayn, the author of the book, said: We have mentioned the famous cities specifically for each city; let us now mention the places in sum and generally, seeking brevity and conciseness. And Allah is the Granter of success to what is right.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The Land of the Berbers and its Mention
It is in the Fourth Clime. It is vast, taking [in] the north and the south across the width of the Fourth and Third Climes, up to the first borders of the Land of the Sudan [Sub-Saharan Africa] in the south, to the Levantine Sea [Mediterranean Sea] in the north, to the Western Ocean, the Greatest Ocean [Atlantic Ocean] in the west at Tangier [Tangier, Morocco], and to the land of Ifriqiya [Tunisia] in the east. Among its cities is the city of Tanas [Tenes, Algeria] «1». It is on the Levantine Sea and is a port for those crossing from the Sea of Andalusia, entering the city of Bajjana [Pechina, Spain] «2». It is a beautiful city with abundant good things, containing a mosque. Its people eat dogs, and there are butchers in it who cut up their meat. Between Qastiliya [Tozeur region, Tunisia] «3» and Tahart [Tiaret, Algeria] is a journey of ten days, and to Fes [Fez, Morocco] is fifteen days, through deserts and sands.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: The city of Fes [Fez, Morocco] has abundant good things. In it is a congregational mosque, flowing waters, trees, and rivers «4». On the Levantine Sea [Mediterranean Sea], in what faces the Island of Andalusia [Iberian Peninsula], are many cities, including: The city of Qartajannah [Cartagena, Spain], the city of Malila [Melilla, Spain], Tlemcen [Tlemcen, Algeria], and the city of Nakur [Nekor, Morocco] «5» up to the city of Tangier [Tangier, Morocco]. It is near the city of Ceuta [Ceuta, Spain]. It is the port and the crossing point to the Island of Andalusia. Beyond Tangier, heading in the direction of the south, is the city of Aghmat [Aghmat, Morocco] «6» and other cities, up to the city of Sijilmasa [Sijilmasa, Morocco] «7», which is the end of the land of the Berbers next to the Sudan [Sub-Saharan Africa].

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The Land of the Sudan [Land of the Blacks]
It is large and vast, taking in length from the Sea of the West [Atlantic Ocean] «1» to the Sea of al-Qulzum [Red Sea]. It is great and majestic. Between the city of Ghana [Ghana Empire, Mauritania/Mali] «2» and the land of Nubia [Sudan/Egypt], there are many lands of deserts and sands. The land of Nubia has intense heat, little rain, few rivers, plants, and trees. Its people walk naked due to the intensity of the heat among them; the woman covers her private parts and nothing else. They raise their children in holes they make in the sand. It is a land with many lions, wild beasts, and terrible, huge animals. Their land has much gold, but they prefer yellow copper (brass/bronze) over

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: gold; they make jewelry from it for women around the waists. The land of Nubia is [on the east of the Nile, and their capital is Dunqula (Dongola)] «3». They take the skins of mules and wear them for years; they do not tear due to their durability. The capital of the land of Abyssinia [Ethiopia] is the city of Jarmi «4»; it is the abode of the Kingdom of Abyssinia, belonging to the Najashi (Negus). In it, gold dust is bought with copper. Its people do not understand [foreign languages]. If a merchant wants to trade with one of them, he places [what he desires to] «5» give him on the ground. If he is pleased with it, he takes it; if he is not pleased, he takes his gold and leaves. Among their cities is the city of Zaghawa [Zaghawa, Chad/Sudan] «6», which is the border of the land of Nubia on the Nile, the city of Kus [Qus, Egypt], the city of Kawkaw [Gao, Mali] «7», and the city of Alwa [Alodia, Sudan] in the land of Nubia on the Nile «8».

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: The land of Nubia is on the canal between the Nile and the river that comes from beneath the Equator. Whatever is behind these lands in the south is uninhabited due to the intensity of the heat there.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The Island of Andalusia [Iberian Peninsula]
It is large, surrounded by seas. It takes from the Western Sea in length at the city of Ukhshunba [Ossónoba/Faro, Portugal] «1» to the junction of the Southern Sea and the Ocean, at the Mountain of Haykal al-Zuhara (Temple of Venus) «2», in what neighbors it, and the city of Tarkuna [Tarragona, Spain] «3» and the city of Barshiluna [Barcelona, Spain], and there is the Gate of Andalusia. It takes in width the Fifth and Sixth Climes from the Levantine Sea [Mediterranean] in the south to the Ocean in the north. The capital of Andalusia is the city of Qurtuba [Cordoba, Spain] «4». It is the abode of the Sunnah,

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: and the gathering place of every marvel. There is nothing like it in the world, so that suffices from mentioning [details about] it. Among the cities of Andalusia is the city of Ishbiliya [Seville, Spain] «5», which is in the west. It is a city of abundant goods and olive trees. It is on the great river that [passes through] Cordoba «6». Among its cities: The city of Tulaytula [Toledo, Spain] «7», which is noble and ancient. It was the capital «8» and the abode of the kingdom for the Goths, and it is fortified. Among its cities: The city of Saraqusta [Zaragoza, Spain] «9», which is great, wondrous, with many rivers, orchards, and trees on Wadi Shalun [Jalon River]. And Jilliq «10», which resembles Iraq and imitates al-Sadir and al-Khawarnaq, and the Upper March (Al-Thagh al-A'la) in what neighbors the land of the Shamakisa. From the Eastern March is Washqa [Huesca, Spain] «11», and opposite it is the land of the Franks,

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: and Tutila [Tudela, Spain] «12», and opposite it is the land of Shalun (Chalon?), and Qal'at Ayyub [Calatayud, Spain] «13» and Madinat Salim [Medinaceli, Spain] «14», and opposite it is Aragon [Aragon, Spain], and Barbashtar [Barbastro, Spain] «15» and Larida [Lleida, Spain] «16» and Massun [Monzón, Spain] «17» and Qallahra [Calahorra, Spain] «18», and opposite it is the land of Qashtala [Castile, Spain] «19». Among the cities of Andalusia is the city of Marida [Merida, Spain] «20», which was the capital of the Goths. Whatever is behind the land of Jaliqiya [Galicia, Spain] «21» takes in the north to the Southern Ocean. Among its cities is the city of Balansiya [Valencia, Spain] «22», which is near the sea, and its capital today is Al-Mariyah [Almeria, Spain] «23», which is on the Levantine Sea. Likewise,

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: the city of Malaqa [Malaga, Spain] «24», which has much good. And the city of Tartusha [Tortosa, Spain], which is on the Levantine Sea «25» adjacent to the land of the Franks. And the city of Ibrara (Evora?) «26», and its capital today is Daniya [Denia, Spain], opposite the two islands of Manurqa [Menorca, Spain] and Mayurqa [Mallorca, Spain] «27». The Island of Andalusia was conquered in the month of Ramadan of the year ninety-two «28». Tariq bin Ziyad al-Nafzi «29» conquered it; he was the agent of Musa bin Nusayr, the agent of Al-Walid bin Abd al-Malik over the lands of Ifriqiya. The King of the Goths in Andalusia was called Ghitisha (Witiza/Roderic context) «30». He had four cities he moved to during the four seasons of the year. He was in

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: the winter season in the city of Toledo [Toledo, Spain], which was the abode «31» of his kingdom. He was in Seville [Seville, Spain] during the fasting days (Lent) for the sake of the fish (Whale), since meat is forbidden to them in their fast. He was in the city of Merida [Merida, Spain] during the days of spring due to the abundance of hunting, clarified butter, and honey there. And he was in Cordoba [Cordoba, Spain] during the days of Pentecost (Ansara) for fruits and drinks. When he entered Seville [after besieging it for months] «32», he annexed it to himself, and that was difficult for the people of his kingdom. The agent (Julian) rebelled against the Island (Algeciras/Ceuta) and built there. He came to Musa bin Nusayr and announced to him the news of Andalusia and its goodness, and ordered him to rise to it to fight it «33». He did not resolve on that until he went to Al-Walid and informed him of that. Al-Walid prevented him and said: "The frontiers of the Muslims are in the sea." He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, I will send Tariq with my army along with the Berbers. If they succeed, it is ours; and if they are stricken, it is not upon us, for they are like enemies." So he ordered him to rise for that. When Tariq crossed the sea, he went out to the mountain attributed to him [Gibraltar]. Then he put forward the Sudan (Blacks) for the war. When the Goths saw terrible forms,

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: that terrified them. The Sudan used to take captives from the Goths and Christians and slaughter them, showing that they were eating them. That increased their fear and panic. Tariq did not pass by a city but that its people fled in fear of him, until he ended up at Toledo. The King had been killed, and Ludhriq (Roderic) succeeded him in his place, so Tariq killed him as well. Christendom was defeated from the towns and plains until they fortified themselves in the rugged terrains and mountains. Obedience to the Muslims reached up to Jaliqiya [Galicia, Spain] and Ifranja (Frankish lands). He made peace with its people, so they used to pay the tribute until their wealth decreased. They became poor and refused it, so he sent armies out to them and drove them into the farthest lands, so they scattered in them.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The Romans (Byzantines) and the Franks «1»
These are many vast lands, taking in length from the Gate of Andalusia [Pyrenees] along the Levantine Sea [Mediterranean] to the city of Constantinople [Istanbul, Turkey]. And in width, to the land of the Saqaliba (Slavs) «2» in the width of the Seventh Clime. They fight the Slavs and enslave them. They are in many islands of the sea. Their lands are cold, with much rain, fruits, mountains, and rugged terrains. [And among] their cities is the city of Rumiyah al-Kubra (Rome the Great), which is on the sea.

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text:
The City of Rumiyah [Rome, Italy]
It is in the Sixth Clime. Its distance from the western line is thirty-five degrees, and from the Equator is forty-two degrees. It is a great city, the abode of the Kingdom of the Romans in ancient times. There is no city in their lands [more beautiful] than it nor greater. Its length is twenty-eight miles. It has two walls, and between them is a great river [Tiber] coming from the sea, upon which are homes and shops [built with yellow copper/brass] «1», because that river is paved with yellow copper in rows and dams ... «2» upon all the people of its work. A great amount of copper was gathered,

book_title: Akam al-Marjan fi Dhikr al-Mada'in al-Mashhura fi Kulli Makan
text: so the edge of the river was paved with it, in what faces the city. From that time, the Christians date from [the Era of] Copper. In the middle of the city is the Great Church [St. Peter's Basilica] «3». Its length is two farsakhs. In it is the grave of Sham'un (Simon/Peter) the Disciple, [one of the disciples of Isa bin Maryam, peace be upon him]. When it is the day of the feast, the King comes, opens the door of the palace, descends into it, shaves his head, then goes out and gives every single man of the people of his kingdom a hair; they seek blessings through it. The walls of the church are adorned with gold. In it are a thousand crosses of gold, and twelve crosses according to the number of the Disciples. In the church are five thousand priests and deacons. In it are one thousand two hundred cups of gold, encrusted with jewels, for drinking wine [and] for the Eucharist. In it is a house (hall) fifty cubits long, furnished with brocade, for the sitting of the deacons, and upon them are clothes of brocade. In the church is a column pillar of red ruby; the house lights up from it at night, and no lamp is needed with it. In the church is a man (statue) built of copper, and on top of it is a starling (Zarzur) of copper. The City of Constantinople [Istanbul, Turkey]
It is in the Sixth Clime. Its distance from the western line is forty-nine degrees, and from the Equator is forty-five degrees. It is a great, noble city, having [no] equal. [It has] three «1» gates and sides: two sides to the sea, and a side to the land towards the Romans. That is because he was the first to enter the religion of the Christians and manifest it, and believed in Isa [Jesus] [peace be upon him].
